div1.p: This outline lists chapter titles and provides rough descriptions of their content.

div1.head: Outline for Philip Showalter Hench's book on yellow fever and Walter Reed, [1950]
div1.p:
WITH WALTER REED IN CUBA (1900)
In memoriam - 1950
Edited and partly written by P. S. Hench

list.item: 2. Preface by P. S. Hench: How I got the subsequent items.
3. Letter and photograph of Mrs. Walter Reed.
4. Chapter 1. Brief outline of the story of the conquest of Yellow Fever (P.S.H.)

5. Chapter 2. General Reed's recollections
Include his remarks on his being in Cuba at the time; what
he knows of his father's work; his amusing comments regarding
its relative “unimportance,” his afterthoughts on the whole affair.

6. Chapter 3. General Kean's recollections. Begin with Dr. Reed's visit
to Kean's sick bed; Kean's first recollections of the work of
Lazear and Agramonte (prior to Reed's arrival) and that of the
commission, especially of Dr. Reed; Kean's relationship to the
commission (to what extent official--to what extent enthusiastically
voluntary; Kean's reactions to Lazear's death, his cooperation re
function of Camp Lazear, etc.

7. Chapter 4. Excerpts from Lazear's notes in the “lost note-book” (New York
Academy note-book).

8. Chapter 5. General Truby's story (revised) of Lazear's death and his ideas
on Lazear's experimental sickness.
9. Chapter 6. Mr. Moran's own personal story (I already have this).
10. Chapter 7. Mr. Kissinger's own personal story (I already have this).
11. Chapter 8. Dr. Cooke's personal story (I have some; it should be amplified)

12. Chapter 9. Excerpts from Dr. Reed's notes in the “lost note-book” (New York
Academy note-book).
13. Chapter 10. Walter Reed's last paper, 40% of which was never published.
15. Chapter 12. The re-discovery of the lost Camp Lazear (1940)(P.S.H.)

div1.p:
Note: If necessary, omit Chapter 15, but its inclusion might help raise money
to preserve the camp site and restore the little building.
